TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant , Mr ORG , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The second applicant , Mr Antanas Gasparavičius , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . DATE the first applicant was an employee of the NORP branch of ORG ( hereinafter the “ ORG ” ) . Thereafter he found employment as a lawyer in a private telecommunications company .

On DATE CARDINAL authorities - ORG and ORG into the Genocide and Resistance of the NORP People - jointly concluded that the applicant was subject to the restrictions imposed LAW ( ORG , ORG , ORG , ORG ) and ORG ( hereinafter “ the LAW ” , see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The conclusion confirmed that the applicant had the status of a “ former ORG officer ” as construed by LAW . As a result , on DATE he was dismissed from his job at the telecommunications company .

CARDINAL . The applicant brought an administrative action against the security intelligence authorities , arguing that his dismissal under LAW and the resultant inability to find employment were unlawful .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found that the conclusion of DATE had been substantiated , and that the applicant was subject to the restrictions imposed under LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the applicant 's appeal .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE , ORG and ORG into the Genocide and Resistance of the NORP People jointly concluded that the applicant had the status of a “ former ORG officer ” , and that he was thereby subject to the restrictions imposed LAW . On DATE the Bar informed him that he would be disbarred pursuant to that law .

CARDINAL . The applicant brought an administrative action , claiming that his dismissal from the Bar would be unlawful . While the applicant did not contest the fact that he had worked for the ORG even following the declaration of NORP independence on DATE , he submitted that thereafter he had worked as an informer for the authorities of independent GPE . Furthermore , throughout his time at the ORG the applicant had allegedly only worked with cases concerning purely criminal investigations , not political persecutions . In the applicant 's view , he had been entitled to be exempted from the employment restrictions , in accordance with LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the applicant 's claim . The court found that he had indeed worked with criminal investigations while at the ORG , but that he had remained employed there until his retirement in DATE . The court held that the exceptions in LAW were not applicable to the applicant , given that he did not end his employment with the ORG immediately after GPE 's declaration of independence on DATE .

CARDINAL . Upon the applicant 's appeal , on DATE ORG upheld this decision . The court reiterated that the applicant was not entitled to be exempted under LAW , as he had not ended his ORG employment immediately after DATE . Moreover , there was no plausible evidence attesting that thereafter the applicant had worked at the ORG as an agent of the authorities of independent GPE .
CARDINAL . As a result of the proceedings on CARDINAL DATE the applicant was disbarred .
CARDINAL . He has now found employment in the business field .

CARDINAL . Following the examination by ORG of the compatibility of the LAW with LAW ( see LAW below ) , on CARDINAL DATE LAW was amended to the effect that even those individuals who had worked for the ORG after CARDINAL DATE could be eligible for exceptions under LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE a separate law on the implementation of the Act was adopted . According to that law , ORG into the Genocide and Resistance of the NORP People and ORG were empowered to reach a conclusion on an individual 's status as a “ former permanent employee of the ORG ” for the purposes of the Act .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Government adopted a list ( “ the list ” ) of positions in various branches of the ORG on NORP territory attesting to a person 's status as a “ former permanent employee of the ORG ” ( “ former ORG officer ” ) for the purposes of the LAW . CARDINAL different positions were listed in this respect .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined the issue of the compatibility of the LAW with LAW . ORG held in particular that the LAW had been adopted in order to carry out “ security screening ” measures on former NORP security officers , who were deemed to be lacking in loyalty to ORG . ORG decided that the prohibition on former ORG agents ' occupying public posts was compatible with the LAW . It further ruled that the statutory ban on the holding by former ORG employees of jobs in certain private sectors was compatible with the constitutional principle of a free choice of profession in that the ORG was entitled to lay down specific requirements for persons applying for work in the most important economic sectors in order to ensure the protection of national security and proper functioning of the educational and financial systems . ORG also held that the restrictions under LAW did not amount to a criminal charge against former ORG agents .

CARDINAL . While the Act does not specifically guarantee a right of access to a court to contest the security intelligence authorities ' conclusion , it was recognised by the domestic courts that , as a matter of practice , a dismissal from employment in the public service on the basis of that conclusion gave rise to an administrative court action ( and a further appeal ) under the general procedure governing industrial disputes and alleged breaches of personal rights by the public authorities , pursuant to Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL of LAW , LAW and LAW as effective at the material time ) .

CARDINAL . Restrictions have been imposed in many post - communist countries with a view to screening the employment of former security agents or active collaborators in the former regimes . In this respect , international human rights bodies have at times found fault with similar legislation where this has lacked precision or proportionality , characterising such rules as discrimination in employment or the exercise of a profession on the basis of political opinion . The possibility of appeal to the courts has been considered a significant safeguard , although not sufficient in itself to make good shortcomings in legislation ( see NORP and PERSON , ORG . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and DATE , CARDINAL , § § DATE , ECHR DATE ... ) .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW provides :
“ With a view to ensuring the effective exercise of the right to work , the Parties undertake :
CARDINAL ) to protect effectively the right of the worker to earn his living in an occupation freely entered upon[. ] ”

This provision , which was retained word for word in LAW of DATE ( which entered into force with regard to GPE on DATE ) , has been consistently interpreted by ORG ) as establishing a right not to be discriminated against in employment . The non - discrimination guarantee is stipulated in Article E of LAW in the following terms :

“ The enjoyment of the rights set forth in this LAW shall be secured without discrimination on any ground such as race , colour , sex , language , religion , political or other opinion , national extraction or social origin , health , association with a national minority , birth or other status . ”

CARDINAL . ORG ( ORG ) has also adopted a number of relevant international legal instruments . The most pertinent text is ORG . CARDINAL on ORG ) of DATE . In its DATE ORG , ORG on ORG ( ORG ) restated its interpretation of Convention No . CARDINAL , drawing upon examples taken from national law .
A DATE survey identifies comparable provisions in the national law of a number of NORP countries .

In GPE , ORG CARDINAL and LAW DATE prohibit the employment of persons who worked for or with the NORP security services . In DATE the ORG expressed its dissatisfaction with the above texts in the following terms :

“ CARDINAL . The ORG recalls that requirements of a political nature can be set for a particular job , but to ensure that they are not contrary to the LAW , they should be limited to the characteristics of a particular post and be in proportion to its labour requirements . The ORG notes that the above established exclusions by the provisions under examination apply broadly to the entire civil service and police rather than to specific jobs , functions or tasks . The ORG is concerned that these provisions appear to go beyond justifiable exclusions in respect of a particular job based on its inherent requirements as provided for LAW . The ORG recalls that for measures not to be deemed discriminatory under LAW , they must be measures affecting an individual on account of activities he or she is justifiably suspected or proven to be engaged in which are prejudicial to the security of the ORG . LAW does not exclude from the definition of discrimination measures taken by reason of membership of a particular group or community . ORG also notes that in cases where persons are deemed to be justifiably suspected of or engaged in activities prejudicial to the security of the ORG , the individual concerned shall have the right to appeal to a competent body in accordance with national practice .

CARDINAL . In the light of the above , the ORG considers the exclusions from being a candidate for any civil service position and from being employed by the police are not sufficiently well defined and delimited to ensure that they do not become discrimination in employment and occupation based on political opinion ... ”
